rooms.Name: The Docks at Waterdeep Harbor
rooms.Description:
As you step onto the docks of Waterdeep Harbor, you can't help but be
impressed by the sheer size of the city known throughout the North as
the City of Splendors. The city sprawls on for miles, it seems, and
the population must be incredible. All around you are people who have
come to this city for trade, travel, and pleasure, and more than a few
who are here for less inicent reasons. Waterdeep is still a frontier city
in some ways. Those who feel a need for adventure can still find it, and
many look for it. You can separate the adventures on the street from the
guardsman and thugs easily; adventurers like yourself tend to stand out
in a crowd. If too many of these sort of people got out of hand, it would
be more than the city guard could handle. 
      But toward the southern side of the city you see why Waterdeep has
remained safe and prosperous...Blackstaff Tower. The tower is home to the
Lord Mage of Waterdeep, Khelben Arunsun, known as the "Blackstaff."

rooms.Name: On the Streets of Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
You are standing on one of the main streets of Waterdeep. You have to
wade through a sea of bodies to make any progress through the streets.
If it weren't for the presence of the Guard, this crowd might get ugly.
Good thing the guardsmen seem to be well trained at handling this sort of
thing.

rooms.Name: Inside the Northern Gate of Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
You are standing in front of one of the city gates. To the North, lies
the road leading to smaller cities and frontier towns, as well as trading
posts and barbarian villages. The fact that the road leads into the
untamed wilderness seems to deter few of the merchants who are constantly
passing through the gate out of the city. Those who enter through the gate
seem none the worse for the experience, and often come bearing carts
loaded with goods from the far North. You start to wonder just how safe
the northern roads are though, when you notice that every caravan leaving
the city takes with it several well-armed guards, and that the caravans
returning seem to have fewer, in general, than the ones leaving.

rooms.Name: On the Streets of Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
Everywhere you turn, you see more people. All going about their jobs
as if it were perfectly normal to be dodging around horse-carts and
pushing through crowds to go anywhere, you wonder at the mindset of 
the citizens of this city. For all the apparent chaos, the workings
of the marketplace and the city in general seem remarkable efficient.
Whoever is running this city has done an excellent job of keeping the
large population under control.

rooms.Name: Holding Cell
rooms.Description:
This is a combination holding cell/drunk tank, used by the Watch to
temporarily house those who have caused the good citizens of Waterdeep
a little too much trouble recently. The smell of alcohol and unwashed
bodies is strong...quite strong. It seems as if most of the residents
of this cell come in sweaty and drunk, and leave sweaty and sober; and
no one washes the place out in between. Not really the ideal place to
spend the night.

Exits.Description:
You see a sturdy iron door with a small window that can be opened from 
the other side only. There is also a slot near the floor - presumably
for a tray of food to be passed through. *sigh* looks like you might be
here a while.

rooms.Name: Sword Street
rooms.Description:
This is one of the main streets of Waterdeep. The hustle and bustle of
hundreds of merchants, tradesmen, and street performers is dizzying. Back
to the west are the docks of Waterdeep Harbor, and off a way to the south
you can see a large tower. Now, if only you can find your way around in 
this crowd.

rooms.Name: The Yawning Portal Inn
rooms.Description:
The clanking of drinks an the sounds of drunken revelry make it hard to
hear yourself think. The smell of something cooking lures you in though.
All around you are what appear to be travellers and adventurers - it
appears that this particular inn has earned a bit renown even outside
the city. Many of the partons carry weapons with casual ease, but seem
relaxed and cheerful, and obviously mean no harm to fellow adventurers.

Exits.Description: It looks as if one of the floorboards is a trifle loose...hmmmm.

rooms.Name: On the Street of Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
This seems to be a relatively quiet part of the city. It's not that there
are fewer people here, but the normally loud, rough corwd seems to be a 
bit more subdued. It probably has something to do with the fact that there
is a guardhouse immediately to the east of here. It also doesn't take
much to figure out why the guardhouse is here. With all the foreigners
who frequent the inn nearby, the Guard is needed frequently.

rooms.Name: Headquarters of the City Watch
rooms.Description:
This is one of several headquarters for the Waterdeep militia. The office
you are currently standing in has a desk, with several forms that can be
filled out to report anything from theft and murder, to the occasional act
of magical espionage. Along the walls, there are racks for the equipment of
off-duty guardsmen, but all of them are empty right now. There must be something
big going on for that many guards to be on duty at one time.
     You notice a holding cell with several drunks and troublemakers, as well
as the offices of the higher ranking officers in the Guard and the Watch, 
but those are strictly off-limits.

rooms.Name: Sword Street
rooms.Description:
Sword Street runs as far as you can see to the north and south. The mob
of people that seems to be present throughout the city is as bad here
as it is anywhere. You start to feel a little claustrophobic with all 
these people all around you. Then, you notice a small, exotic bookstore
that seems to have few customers, and you think that it might be a nice
break from the frenzy outside.

rooms.Name: A Stuffy Old Bookstore
rooms.Description:
As you enter the room, you hear the tinkle of one of those annoying
little bells that shopkeepers use to let them know when a customer
enters (usually so they can harrass them into buying something). You 
take a look at one of the books, and the cloud of dust that rises from
the book when you touch it makes you sneeze. It seems as if most of the
books here have been untouched for QUITE some time. There is a display
case in the back of the room, its glass tinted yellow with age. In the
case, the owner of the store keeps what he apparently believes to be his
most valuable works...not much to look at as far as you can tell. At 
least the quiet is a relief from the chaos outside.

Exits.Description:
The cord to an old pull-down, folding set of stair is hanging from the 
cieling.

ExtraDescs.Description:
The inside of the glass case isn't very well-lit, but from what you can
see the books inside are truly ancient. You can see gold lettering, on
some of them, written in an obscure, dead language. If you want to
find out any more about the books, you're probably going to have to
subject yourself to a history lesson from whatever old windbag runs
this place...not worth it.

rooms.Name: On the Streets of Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
This road is the main thoroughfare for merchants bringing their wares to
the markets in the sourthern part of the city. The guards here try to keep
you away from the merchants. After all, it just wouldn't do to have rich
merchants bothered by ruffians, now would it?

rooms.Name: Inside the East gate of Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
This is the eastern gateway into the City of Splendors. Through this gate
lies the untamed wilderness, and some of the largest trading roads
in the North. Rumors in the city suggest that this road is no longer
safe...caravans have been disappearing....

rooms.Name: Sword Street
rooms.Description:
This part of Sword Street seems to be less crowded than it was father to the
north. You only wonder briefly why that is, thankful as you are for any relief
from the noisy crowd. With the relative quiet, you can get a better look out
over the cityscape, and once again you can see Blackstaff Tower off to the
South.

rooms.Name: The Temple of Mystra
rooms.Description:
The temple is clean and pleasant. Though there are no visible light sources
the room is well-lit; but this is a place of magic after all. A circular 
altar draws you attention to the middle of the temple.

ExtraDescs.Description: The inscription on the base of the altar reads: "I am the One True Spell"

rooms.Name: On the Streets of Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
All these streets are starting to look the same. People, shops, people, 
shops...Then you notice a more pleasant looking building: the Temple of
Mystra. To the west you see that the temple's doors are open to anyone
whether or not they worship the Lady of Mysteries. Oh, and to the east is
another shop *groan*

rooms.Name: General Store
rooms.Description:
This store has it all. Everything the adventurer needs to survive is sold
here...at least the shopkeeper says so. He does seem to have a pretty large
inventory though. The fine clothing the shopkeeper is wearing though, suggeests
that his prices might be a bit high

rooms.Name: Before Blackstaff Tower
rooms.Description:
You notice that the congestion of Waterdeep isn't nearly as severe here.
For a second, you wonder if this might not be the safest part of town.
But as you walk, you enter the shadow of an enormous tower. That explains
things, since Blackstaff Tower is home to one of the most powerful archmages
in all the realms, as well as Lord Protector of Waterdeep, Khelben Arunsun,
also known as the "Blackstaff."

Exits.Description: It might be a way into Blackstaff Tower
It might be a way into Blackstaff Tower

rooms.Name: A Street in Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
You can't help but be impressed with the sights of the city. From this
vantage point, you can see out over the harbor, where huge galleons
are docked. To the west, you can see Blackstaff Tower.

rooms.Name: A Street in Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
This is one of the main marketplaces in Waterdeep. Caravans from all over
the world come here to sell their goods, and buy others. You could find
almost anything here if you looked hard enough. Even those rare shops that
sell magical items can be found here. In fact, there is one just to the
east.

rooms.Name: Ye Olde Magick Shoppe
rooms.Description:
This tidy little shop is run be a Cormyrian merchant who has settled down
into a lucrative business...selling magic. He is very knowledgeably and
carries most of the magical neccesities demanded by adventurers. A glass 
display case shows off his wares.

rooms.Name: Blackstaff Tower
rooms.Description:
The entranceway to Blackstaff Tower is much like what you'd expect to find
In the home of a wealthy merchant. The furnishings in this room seem to
indicate that it is used as a sitting room for entertaining guests.
The chiars are well-cushioned and seem to be accustomed to frequent use. 
You're tempted to sit down and take a well-deserved rest, but then you
hear voices from upstairs, and remember that you're an uninvited guest. A set
of spiral stairs leads up.

Exits.Description:
You see the tell-tale bluish fires of magical wards, and wonder if its
really safe to be going up there. Only one way to find out.

rooms.Name: Apprentices' Laboratories
rooms.Description:
This is the the room where all of Khleben and Laeral's apprentices learn
the rudiments of spellcasting. The room is heavily warded to protect
against any accidents the newbie mages might make. There is a table in the
middle of the room, on which lies the components necessary for casting the
most basic of spells. Arrayed around the table are enough stools for all
the apprentices to crowd around. In front of each apprentice is a spellbook
which is very nearly blank.

Exits.Description: This is the way to the man himself. Take a deep breath and just do it.
Ahhh, chickening out I see. Well, back down seems the safest course.

ExtraDescs.Description:
Even without formal magical training you'd be able to read the few
spells these apprentices know. The page all the books are open to has
the spells 'detect invisible' and 'magic missile'.

rooms.Name: Khelben's Study and Spell Laboratory
rooms.Description:
This is Khelben's personal study. On a desk in one corner of the
room are several spell-scrolls that are drying after being newly
scribed. Behind a bookshelf you notice some kind of vault.

ExtraDescs.Description:
The vault appears to be magically held shut. You doubt that it is within
your power to open it.

rooms.Name: Theives' Guild Hideout
rooms.Description:
The shadows are deep here; this isn't a place for those who want to be
seen. Several thieves are occupying themselves with games of "chance,"
which actually involve a lot less chance the way they seem to be playing.
There are tables at which a few off-duty thugs and cat-burglers talk 
among themselves, discussing the day's business. In the shadows though,
lurk more sinister creatures. Though human, these men are as much predators
as any wild beast. They prey on anyone...for the right price. As, you
enter, every eye in the room turns to look at you. You try to act casual.

rooms.Name: A Small Reading Room in the Bookstore's Attic
rooms.Description:
Old books, papers, and scrolls cover every surface in this little room. The
person who uses this room is obviously a voracious reader.

rooms.Name: A Narrow Rune-Engraved Tunnel
rooms.Description:
YEEEEEEEEEOOOOOOOOUUUUUUUUCCCCCCCCCCCCCHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Remember to throttle whoever was paranoid and vengeful enough to place
a spell-trap on what appeared to be a perfectly safe secret entrance to
his home. How DARE he put traps to defend...his private...property. Well,
looking back on it, maybe it was you fault for trying to break in. Oh
well, looks like you're going to get some time to think over what you've 
done. The only way out is into a holding cell.

rooms.Name: Outside the Northern Gate of Waterdeep
rooms.Description:
You see the vast wilderness before you and question the wisdom of trying
to make your way across it. The way before you is not lightly travelled, for
foul creatures make their home in that region. It isn't too late to turn back.

rooms.Name: The Untamed Wilderness of the Northlands
rooms.Description:
While the sights of the fields and copses of trees is pleasant, you know better
than to let your guard down. Monsters could lurk around any corner.

rooms.Name: The Untamed Wilderness of the Northlands
rooms.Description:
While the sights of the fields and copses of trees is pleasant, you know better
than to let your guard down. Monsters could lurk around any corner.

rooms.Name: The Untamed Wilderness of the Northlands
rooms.Description:
While the sights of the fields and copses of trees is pleasant, you know better
than to let your guard down. Monsters could lurk around any corner.

rooms.Name: The Untamed Wilderness of the Northlands
rooms.Description:
While the sights of the fields and copses of trees is pleasant, you know better
than to let your guard down. Monsters could lurk around any corner.

rooms.Name: The Untamed Wilderness of the Northlands
rooms.Description:
While the sights of the fields and copses of trees is pleasant, you know better
than to let your guard down. Monsters could lurk around any corner.

rooms.Name: A Trail Leading Toward a Desert
rooms.Description:
You notice a subtle shift in the normally hilly terrain. The path you are 
following levels out somewhat and off in the distance you think you see
what looks like a desert, but you hope it is just some parched terrain. 
You wouldn't relish the thought of crossing an entire desert.

rooms.Name: A Path into the Desert
rooms.Description:
Your worst fears have been confirmed. Once you can get a good look out
to the east, you are sure that this is one BIG desert. Though it seems that
you can see out a few hundred miles, you don't see anything to indicate
where the other side might be. If you try crossing, you'd better have plenty
of provisions....this might take a while.

rooms.Name: The Untamed Wilderness of the Northlands
rooms.Description:
While the sights of the fields and copses of trees is pleasant, you know better
than to let your guard down. Monsters could lurk around any corner.

rooms.Name: The Base of a Mountain Range
rooms.Description:
To your north is the largest mountain range in the world...a wall of stone.
Marking the northern boundary of civilization, the Spine of the World spans
thousands of miles in length. While much of the lands south of the range
are still wild, nothing north of the Spine can reasonably be considered 
civilized.

rooms.Name: The Spine of the World Mountains
rooms.Description:
You are on a path leading among, but seemingly not through the mountains.
According to legend, the ancient dwarven city of Mithril Hall is located
somewhere around this region. Even having a rough-edged dwarven city as
a refuge would be welcome in this severe evnironment.

rooms.Name: The Spine of the World Mountains
rooms.Description:
You are on a path leading among, but seemingly not through the mountains.
According to legend, the ancient dwarven city of Mithril Hall is located
somewhere around this region. Even having a rough-edged dwarven city as
a refuge would be welcome in this severe evnironment.

rooms.Name: The Spine of the World Mountains
rooms.Description:
You are on a path leading among, but seemingly not through the mountains.
According to legend, the ancient dwarven city of Mithril Hall is located
somewhere around this region. Even having a rough-edged dwarven city as
a refuge would be welcome in this severe evnironment.

rooms.Name: A Path in the Mounatins
rooms.Description:
This path is a little more open than the ones you came from. You notice
that down a trecherous slope, there is what appears to be the ruins of an
old city. The only thing that seems to be left are some of the stone walls
of a few of the buildings.

rooms.Name: The Ruins
rooms.Description:
This is the ruin of the dwarven city of Dwarvendarrow, called Settlestone by
outsiders. Though the city was abandoned centuries ago, the walls of the
stone buildings have not been touched by the years, dwarven craftsmanship
lasting as well as the mountain stone.

rooms.Name: A Dead End
rooms.Description:
You have run out of places to go. The only way you have out of here is
the way you came in. The rock wall here is too step to climb, and there
doesn't even seem to be a trail above it to make a climb worthwhile.

Exits.Description:
When you first look, you don't seem anything. But, on further study, you
notice the almost imperceptible seem in the rock. A secret entrance perhaps?

rooms.Name: An Ominous Hallway
rooms.Description:
This section of the hall seems to be a bit museum-like. Suits of decorative
armor line both sides of the wall, mounted on small pedestals. You think you
hear a slight creaking of metal as you start to pass by the first of the
suits. You've got a bad feeling about this...

rooms.Name: The Middle of the Ominous Hallway
rooms.Description:
This section of the hallway is a welcome relief from the part you just
passed. The only distinguishing feature is the pattern carved into the floor.
Intricate runes flow and intertwine, and...uh oh...runes in a mage's
tower...not a good sign. GULP.

rooms.Name: The Far End of the Ominous Hallway
rooms.Description:
Here's the layout: big stone door; big stone golem blocking the big stone
door. You get the distinct impression that this golem does not want you here,
at least not if you are tying to get throught the door.
   Other than the door itself, the end of the hallway is unremarkable.

rooms.Name: Manshoon's Private Chambers
rooms.Description:
With a reputation like his, you would have though that his room would be a
small museum dedicated to the evils he has perpetrated throughout the
centuries. In fact though, it is tastefully decorated, and appears lavishly
comfortable. The chairs around what appears to be a private meeting table are
covered in felt and thickly padded. Arranged around the room are various works
of art, ranging from paintings and tapestries, to sculptures. The bed on one
side of the room is enormous, and it is "decorated" by a young, sleeping woman
presently. Your guess would be that this is Manshoon's current mistress.

rooms.Name: Sarhthor's Laboratory
rooms.Description:
Unlike the sitting room outside, this laboratory is dark and ominous. The
walls are lined with shelves containing various fluids and concoctions, which
bubble and froth, waiting to be used in some sort of sorcerous endeavor. On
one table there is a large crystal ball, held in place by a carving of a
dismembered hand. On another table lies a flesh golem, presently under
construction, and some *ugh* raw materials for making it.

ExtraDescs.Description:
This grisly undertaking invloves the creation of a host body for a powerful elemental
force to animate. The body of a flesh golem is pieced together from the relatively
intact remains of several dead humanoid creatures. When finished, a flesh golem
is a formiddable opponent, and a valuable tool for a wizard.

rooms.Name: On The Streets of Zhentil Keep
rooms.Description:
You find yourself standing in front of a large building built of jet black
stone. The HUGE holy symbol of Cyric hanging about the door lets even the most
dense of commoners know that this is the Chruch of Cyric. Men in purple robes
occasionally come out of the church, but passers-by are careful to look away
and avoid the notice of these "holy" men of the death god. You would to well
to do the same.

rooms.Name: The hidden entrance to Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This is it....the formerly lost city of Mithril Hall. Rediscovered a few years
ago by Breunor, Drizzt, Wulfgar, and Regis, The Hall has regained the prestige
it had over two centuries ago, when the dwarves were driven away.

rooms.Name: The Hall of Kings
rooms.Description:
This chamber is a tribute to each of the Kings of Mithril Hall. Around the room
are busts of the previous seven kings, ending with Garumn, King of the Hall
at the time of its downfall. An eighth bust, that of King Bruenor, has been
started, but has yet to be finished.

rooms.Name: A Hallway in Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This hallway is somewhat small for humans, but acceptable. It is well lit by
torches burning in sconces along the walls.

rooms.Name: The Hall of Dumathoin
rooms.Description:
This room is breathtaking. Containing the greatest masterpieces of the dwarven
smiths, as well as the most prized gifts received from outsiders, the Hall of
Dumathoin holds more priceless treasures than could be imagined. You used to
think highly of the accomplishments of some human craftsmen but
their works are put to shame by these masterpieces.

rooms.Name: A Hallway in Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This hallway is somewhat small for humans, but acceptable. It is well lit by
torches burning in sconces along the walls.

rooms.Name: Beunor's Room
rooms.Description:
This room is a contradition is almost every way. As befits a king, the
furnishings are of the highest craftsmanship and best material. The dwarves
seem to have spared no expense or effort to make sure their king had the best
of all things.
   The luxuries available are seemingly ignored though. The fine furniture has
been casually pushed aside, and a stool pushed up to the writing desk in a
corner. Papers on the desk are scattered about and held down with a raw chunk
of mithril being used as a paperweight. And a weapons rack hangs empty, while
the axe that should be in it rests against the wall, well used and notched
along the handle, counting its kills in battle.

rooms.Name: A Hallway in Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This hallway is somewhat small for humans, but acceptable. It is well lit by
torches burning in sconces along the walls.

rooms.Name: Catti-Brie's Room
rooms.Description:
While most of the rooms in Mithril Hall are somewhat spartan, this one has a
homey feel to it. The room is fairly neat, and conservatively, but carefully
decorated, with personal touches and objects that seemingly have more
sentimental value than monetary value. The clothes you see are too large for
almost any dwarf, and are meant for a woman, so you assume this must be the
room where Catti-brie, Bruenor's adopted human daughter, lives.

rooms.Name: A Hallway in Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This hallway is somewhat small for humans, but acceptable. It is well lit by
torches burning in sconces along the walls.

rooms.Name: Regis' Room
rooms.Description:
This room looks as if someone just moved in. Things are still are still lying in
piles, having yet to be put away. The possesions of the occupant lead you to
wonder. There are many jewels and gems, and the clothes are of unquestionably
good quality, bordering on foppish. However, a quick count shows that there
were only enough clothes for a couple days. Whoever packed obviously wanted
to be sure to have his riches with him.

rooms.Name: A Hallway in Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This hallway is somewhat small for humans, but acceptable. It is well lit by
torches burning in sconces along the walls.

rooms.Name: Wulfgar's Room
rooms.Description:
This room is definitely not inhabited by a dwarf! The bed, chairs and table
have been specially made, HUGE, for someone who is almost twice the size of
any dwarf in the Hall. Some wolf-skin armor, with the head still attached, is
draped over the chair, and has definitely seen a lot of combat, as several
blood-stains have never gone away. This is obviously the room of a warrior.

rooms.Name: A Hallway in Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This hallway is somewhat small for humans, but acceptable. It is well lit by
torches burning in sconces along the walls.

rooms.Name: A Hallway in Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This hallway is somewhat small for humans, but acceptable. It is well lit by
torches burning in sconces along the walls.

rooms.Name: Drizzt's Room
rooms.Description:
This room is nearly bare. If it weren't for the fact that there is no dust,
you'd suspect that it was vacant. Whoever lives here must not be much on
decorating. The only thing you notice other than the barest of furnishings is
a figurine resting on the table, depicting a great, black hunting cat....a
panther.

rooms.Name: Walkway between the Upper Halls and the Undercity
rooms.Description:
This is a winding path leading down into the heart of Mithril Hall. You can
hear the ringing of hammer on mithril.

rooms.Name: The Undercity of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This is the heart of Mithril Hall. All around you you hear the sounds of the
dwarven crafts being plied. The peal of the hammer against the anvil, the
rushing of the air in the bellows, heating the forges, and the crack of pick-axe
against stone as miners extract more precious mithril from the lower tunnels.
It's much hotter down here than in the upper halls, and would be intolerable
if not for the chinmeys taking smoke and heat to higher, uninhabited tunnels.

Exits.Description: This is the way into the shrine. Don't worry, you'll be welcome there.

rooms.Name: The Undercity of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This is the heart of Mithril Hall. All around you you hear the sounds of the
dwarven crafts being plied. The peal of the hammer against the anvil, the
rushing of the air in the bellows, heating the forges, and the crack of pick-axe
against stone as miners extract more precious mithril from the lower tunnels.
It's much hotter down here than in the upper halls, and would be intolerable
if not for the chinmeys taking smoke and heat to higher, uninhabited tunnels.

Exits.Description: This is the way into the shrine. Don't worry, you'll be welcome there.

rooms.Name: Entrance to the Undercity
rooms.Description:
The view before you is spectacular. The great Undercity of Mithril Hall can be
seen from one side to the other from here. The immense cavern contains the
homes and workplaces of thousands of dwarves. The heat from the great
forge and the other, smaller forges of the city, bring sweat to your brow. you
take little notice of that slight discomfort, though, as you are in awe of the
scene you see. The undercity is a hive of activity as some of the finest smiths
in all the Realms toil endlessly at the forges, while other dwarves carry out
other activities that are necessary to keep the forges and the city running.

rooms.Name: Shrine to the dwarven gods
rooms.Description:
This humble, well-constructed shine pays homage to the 3 main dwarven gods:
Moradin the Soulforger, god of craft, Dumathoin the Keeper of Secrets Under
the Mountain, and Clanggedin, the dwarven god of battle.
    The small temple is not ornate,the dwarves preferring to honor their gods by
living up to thier doctrines of hard work and fearless devotion. Dwarven often
stop by here to show their latest masterpiece to their appreciative divine
sponsors.

rooms.Name: The Undercity of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This is the heart of Mithril Hall. All around you you hear the sounds of the
dwarven crafts being plied. The peal of the hammer against the anvil, the
rushing of the air in the bellows, heating the forges, and the crack of pick-axe
against stone as miners extract more precious mithril from the lower tunnels.
It's much hotter down here than in the upper halls, and would be intolerable
if not for the chinmeys taking smoke and heat to higher, uninhabited tunnels.

Exits.Description: You shield your eyes from looking into the brightness of the forge.
This is the way into the shrine. Don't worry, you'll be welcome there.

rooms.Name: The Great Central Forge
rooms.Description:
This is the heart and soul of the city. One of the three main forges, this one
is currnetly occupied by a master mithril-smith. You feel very industrious
just standing here...as if Moradin himself were motivating you to go out and
pound a block of mithril into a masterpiece. You manage to resist the
temptation though, since you 'd have no clue where to start.

ExtraDescs.Description:
The forge seems hot enough to melt just about anything. Even standing this
close to it, you feel sweat pouring down your face. The heat is necessary to
soften the incredibly hard mithril used by the dwarven smiths. You suspect that
substances even harder than mithril could be worked in a forge such as this.

rooms.Name: The Undercity of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This is the heart of Mithril Hall. All around you you hear the sounds of the
dwarven crafts being plied. The peal of the hammer against the anvil, the
rushing of the air in the bellows, heating the forges, and the crack of pick-axe
against stone as miners extract more precious mithril from the lower tunnels.
It's much hotter down here than in the upper halls, and would be intolerable
if not for the chinmeys taking smoke and heat to higher, uninhabited tunnels.

Exits.Description: This is the way into the shrine. Don't worry, you'll be welcome there.

rooms.Name: The Undercity of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This is the heart of Mithril Hall. All around you you hear the sounds of the
dwarven crafts being plied. The peal of the hammer against the anvil, the
rushing of the air in the bellows, heating the forges, and the crack of pick-axe
against stone as miners extract more precious mithril from the lower tunnels.
It's much hotter down here than in the upper halls, and would be intolerable
if not for the chinmeys taking smoke and heat to higher, uninhabited tunnels.

Exits.Description: This is the entrance to the shrine. Don't worry, you'll be welcome.

rooms.Name: The Undercity of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
This is the heart of Mithril Hall. All around you you hear the sounds of the
dwarven crafts being plied. The peal of the hammer against the anvil, the
rushing of the air in the bellows, heating the forges, and the crack of pick-axe
against stone as miners extract more precious mithril from the lower tunnels.
It's much hotter down here than in the upper halls, and would be intolerable
if not for the chinmeys taking smoke and heat to higher, uninhabited tunnels.

rooms.Name: The Mines of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
Dwarven mines, unlike those of human design, are not unpleasant places. The
tunnels are large enough to walk without stooping, even for humans, and they
are lit with ever-burning torches. The tunnels of the mine are braced with beams
every 12 feet or so, and the craftsmanship of the dwarves leads you to the
conclusion that these mines will never collapse...unless the dwarves want them
to.

ExtraDescs.Description:
The dwarves need these. You cannot have them. The torches light the mines
so that anyone working here can see what they are doing.

rooms.Name: The Mines of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
Dwarven mines, unlike those of human design, are not unpleasant places. The
tunnels are large enough to walk without stooping, even for humans, and they
are lit with ever-burning torches. The tunnels of the mine are braced with beams
every 12 feet or so, and the craftsmanship of the dwarves leads you to the
conclusion that these mines will never collapse...unless the dwarves want them
to.

ExtraDescs.Description:
The dwarves need these. You cannot have them. The torches light the mines
so that anyone working here can see what they are doing.

rooms.Name: The Mines of Mithril Hall
rooms.Description:
Dwarven mines, unlike those of human design, are not unpleasant places. The
tunnels are large enough to walk without stooping, even for humans, and they
are lit with ever-burning torches. The tunnels of the mine are braced with beams
every 12 feet or so, and the craftsmanship of the dwarves leads you to the
conclusion that these mines will never collapse...unless the dwarves want them
to.

ExtraDescs.Description:
The dwarves need these. You cannot have them. The torches light the mines
so that anyone working here can see what they are doing.

rooms.Name: A Newer Mineshaft
rooms.Description:
The walls of this section of the mines are not as well-worked as in the older
parts of the mine. There's a good reason for this....there's still mithril in them.
The dwarves are working on fixing that though, as miners all around you pound
away with pick-axes.
     There is a small track on which a minecar can run.

rooms.Name: A Newer Mineshaft
rooms.Description:
The walls of this section of the mines are not as well-worked as in the older
parts of the mine. There's a good reason for this....there's still mithril in
them. The dwarves are working on fixing that though, as miners all around you
pound away with pick-axes.
     There is a small track on which a minecar can run.

rooms.Name: A Newer Mineshaft
rooms.Description:
The walls of this section of the mines are not as well-worked as in the older
parts of the mine. There's a good reason for this....there's still mithril in
them. The dwarves are working on fixing that though, as miners all around you
pound away with pick-axes.
     There is a small track on which a minecar can run.

rooms.Name: A Newer Mineshaft
rooms.Description:
The walls of this section of the mines are not as well-worked as in the older
parts of the mine. There's a good reason for this....there's still mithril in
them. The dwarves are working on fixing that though, as miners all around you
pound away with pick-axes.
     There is a small track on which a minecar can run.

rooms.Name: A Little-Used Tunnel
rooms.Description:
It's strangely quiet in this part of the undercity. Not a mine...no forges
here... not even living quarters. Seems that this part of Mithril Hall has
been abandoned by the dwarves.

rooms.Name: A Little-Used Tunnel
rooms.Description:
It's strangely quiet in this part of the undercity. Not a mine...no forges
here... not even living quarters. Seems that this part of Mithril Hall has
been abandoned by the dwarves.

rooms.Name: Garumn's Gorge
rooms.Description:
Hardly a gorge--"canyon" would be more accurate. Spanning hundreds of feet, and
deeper than anyone would care to measure, Garumn's Gorge was once an emergency
escape route from Mithril Hall. However, during Bruenor's initial exploration
of the Halls, a group of Duergar destroyed the bridge...the only way across.
Ever since then, there has been little reason to come here.
    The walls of the gorge are nearly sheer, but if you were reeeeaaaally
careful, you might be able to climb down.

rooms.Name: In Garumn's Gorge
rooms.Description: Well, you seem to be holding on okay. Just don't look down *gulp*

rooms.Name: The Bottom of Garumn's Gorge
rooms.Description:
You're amazed that you managed to survive the climb down. It isn't too
impressive...until you look back up. You nearly faint just thinking about
having to climb back up there.
